unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an in-depth understanding of the U.S. national security and intelligence system and how it is alike and different from the Australian system.

Engage and develop networks with security professionals and academics working in the U.S. system and leverage off those relationships, as well as relationships with your co-study tour participants to enhance knowledge and future collaboration.
Evaluate the ‘Five Eyes’ Intelligence sharing relationship, in particular the roles of the U.S. and Australia in that relationship and the breadth and depth of that relationship.
Apply knowledge learned to connect security and criminology theory to practice in a real-world environment.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Group discussion during the study tour

enrolment_rules.description: Interviews will be held in November during the last week of classes; selection criteria is based upon (a) professionalism and maturity displayed during interview, (b) WAM, (c) the quality of student-submitted Statement of Interest and (d) the diversity of the group.
Admission to MIntell or MSecStrategicStud or MCyberSecAnalysis or MCrim or MCTerrorism

assessments.description: Prepare a 1500-word 'Comparative Assessment', comparing and contrasting the US National and State Security system and processes with the Australian National and State Security system and processes.
Prepare a 3000-word 'Reflective Journal' at the end of the Study Tour, covering a day-by-day assessment and reflection on Study Tour events.

Students will prepare and post an ‘Expression of Interest’ in the DC Study Tour, a short 500-word memo focused on why the student wishes to participate in the study tour and what they would like to get from the Study Tour.

academic_org.value: Department of Security Studies and Criminology

data.description: This unit offers a unique opportunity for students to participate in an overseas study tour of the United States. The study tour focuses upon the security relationship between the United States and Australia. The study tour is hosted by the University of Maryland, College Park, Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START) Department. Students will also visit Washington, D.C. and New York City. The tour allows students to explore, compare and contrast the United States’ national security structure and processes to that of Australia. During this two-week intensive study tour, students will meet, listen and speak with experts from government, academia, and private industry. This will enable students to gain fresh perspectives and insights into contemporary security issues.
data.title: Study Tour
